posts.name: Matthew S.
posts.cooked: Bear Metal 2046 is thrilled to present our 2025 robot “Bearracuda.” The robot features an impressive design with high-resolution imagery showcasing its intricate details. The first image displays a close-up view of the robot’s metallic surface, while the second shows a wider angle highlighting its structural components. For your reference, you can access the CAD model and technical binder via the provided links. Feel free to reach out with any questions!

posts.name: Sam R
posts.cooked: Would you be willing to additionally post your schematics notebook that details your electrical system? Once again, this is a stellar bot from you guys.

posts.name: Anthony Ung
posts.cooked: thank u mr president

posts.name: Anthony Ung
posts.cooked: In developing the coaxially driven robotic shoulder joint, how was the specific gear ratio designed to optimize torque with movement velocity? This optimization was particularly important for applications requiring high speed and precision, such as arm pivots, elevators, and wrist joints. What trade-offs were considered regarding control precision and system responsiveness?

posts.name: Eric Zeng
posts.cooked: To design the coaxially driven floor intake, what specific factors were considered when choosing the ideal material for the roller components to ensure adequate rigidity for collision resistance? How was the optimal hardness level for each tire on the intake determined? Were there any difficulties in powering the indexing system using a single motor instead of the dual-motor setup employed by teams like 2056 and 1690?

posts.name: Matthew S.
posts.cooked: When deciding on the final drive ratio for the arm, ReCalc and manual calculations were used to minimize positioning time. Considering the tradeoffs of a coaxial setup, the key factor was reducing failure modes in the extension into the reef, where the arm is more susceptible to damage. The main challenge was addressing backlash in the entire arm, which was tackled by improving the final belt stage through the front tensioner block.

posts.name: Matthew S.
posts.cooked: We enhanced its performance through the efforts of our R&D team, focusing on fuel efficiency and emissions reduction.

posts.name: Matthew S.
posts.cooked: Get our electrical people to polish that up and have it posted soon.

posts.name: Anthony Ung
posts.cooked: When developing the initial architecture for the robotic pipe scoring machine, our team underwent extensive strategic decision-making processes regarding the selection of a modular omnidirectional coaxially driven swerve system for the drive base. Our game analysis indicated that such a system was indeed necessary to achieve the game's desired level. When evaluating the decision, we considered nuances such as cost, scalability, and future-proofing capabilities. We chose Swerve drive specialties for its unique advantages, including superior performance compared to other commercial off-the-shelf options and a proven track record of reliability and robustness during competitions. Regarding the configuration, based on technical details from our binder, we selected three inverted modular units and one inverted narrow configuration to optimize stability and maneuverability under various operational conditions. This combination allowed us to balance performance requirements with practicality, ensuring optimal functionality across different scenarios.

posts.name: Nolan Evans
posts.cooked:
According to the technical documentation, the team chose to integrate a single Swerve Drive Specialties MK4i Narrow module in an inverted configuration to enhance spatial clearance for their vertical linear actuation system.  
Swerve module selection is inherently application-specific, with each vendor offering distinct tradeoffs based on factors such as packaging geometry, bearing stackup, azimuth motor integration, and wheel accessibility. Ultimately, optimal module selection depends on drivetrain footprint, subsystem interfaces, maintenance needs, and fabrication capabilities. For example, my team previously used West Coast Products Swerve Xi modules in the 2024 season and now use the updated X2i model for 2025, benefiting from improved weight distribution, encoder accessibility, and integrated bevel gear support.

posts.name: Isaac S
posts.cooked: Last year, we had a lengthy discussion about the pros and cons of each COTs swerve module. While I don't remember every detail, last year we went with SDS because of its familiarity and the fact that we didn't have to spend more to acquire a full set. Additionally, because we were able to utilize a MK4n, a point Nolan raised, gave us the necessary spacing to position our elevator between swerves while maintaining a consistent height of 26.5 inches. However, looking back, expanding to approximately 28 inches might have been the better choice, offering extra stability despite the potential increase in weight.

posts.name: Anthony Ung
posts.cooked: What computer-aided design software do you guys utilize to create the robotic pipe-scoring machine?
